Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Agency: Washington State Department of Labor & Industries
Info Source: Contained in data obtained on May 15, 2017 in response to an open records request.

Description: 7-Eleven, Inc. agreed to pay $375,000 and implement new procedures to prevent tobacco sales to minors.
Info Source: https://www.oag.ca.gov/news/press-releases/attorney-general-lockyer-announces-agreement-7-eleven-curb-tobacco-sales-minors
https://web.archive.org/web/20150910052049/http://ago.mo.gov/home/news-archives/2011-news-archives/ag-koster-reaches-agreement-with-7-eleven-for-air-conservation-violations

Description: Agreed to pay a $75,000 civil penalty as part of a settlement of alleged violations from a gasoline leak at one of its gas stations that resulted in several explosions.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20190517195946/http://www.illinoisattorneygeneral.gov/pressroom/2018_12/2018126.html
Speedway Agrees to Pay $80,000 Penalty for Wastewater Discharge Violations, US States News, July 13, 2006 (via Nexis).
https://www.law360.com/articles/1170370/7-eleven-reaches-2m-settlement-over-background-checks

Description: 7-Eleven, Inc. agreed to pay $1.525 million in settlement of allegations by the District Attorneys of Alameda, Contra Costa, Monterey, San Mateo, San Francisco, San Joaquin, Solano, Ventura, and Yolo Counties that it  that it did not implement hazardous materials business plans for the CO2 tanks used in its restaurants for carbonated beverages, which require staff training.
Info Source: https://www.alcoda.org/newsroom/2019/aug/711_settlement#more
https://web.archive.org/web/20090813022624/http://eeoc.gov/litigation/settlements/settlement08-03.html
